snippet.textDisplay:
Interesting point...that's some are being selfish by choosing to live their lives the way that they want to live it. The perspective I'm hearing is that we need to restrict people's lives because 1) by choosing to live socially they're risking others living their lives...this of course is predicated on the notion that somehow those that choose to live socially will socially also be around those that don't want to live socially? 2) that the number of lives that are at risk are at some level that that again...someone else must constrain their lives to help others survive....so what is this number? Is it a specific number? 1, 100? 1,000? 100,000? Where does this stop?
So ~3,000 die in car crashes each day throughout the world...about the same number of deaths in China over the Coronavirus....do we now only allow driving at 20mph? Sorry but this approach is extremely concerning to me as a watershed change in the way we live and govern the world.

snippet.textDisplay:
If a company released a lightweight, cordless, comfortable, affordable VR headset with excellent sound specifically made for movie viewing, then I wouldn't mind just watching all movies from home. And I would pay the full 20$ for them if it was a highly anticipated title.

However, without a good VR set to simulate a theater experience, I would probably pass, unless it was a drama/horror/film that I wouldn't watch for effects--and even then I don't think I would want to pay over 16$.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’m in a wheelchair and we don’t have any movie theaters I can access where I live, so I would love streamable releases of movies. I have gone to the movies twice in my 27 years and none of those times were enjoyable for me. I have no idea about new releases at all, I just ignore them because I know I’ll have to wait like two years to watch them anyway lol

Personally, I wouldn’t be able to justify paying more than a normal movie ticket, which is between 7€ and 9€ here depending on the movie. I can’t help but think that the companies wouldn’t lose that much money if they just released it online and in theaters at the same time. They would possibly make more money if all the people who can’t/don’t want to go to a theater had the opportunity to stream it from home!

snippet.textDisplay:
I went for a drive yesterday just to get out of my apartment. On the way the sheer AMOUNT of kids on the playgrounds baffled me. You can bet those playgrounds aren't getting cleaned and you can bet the kids are sticking their hands everywhere. I hadn't been out in public since last week so I guess I was under the idea that people were actually following social-distancing guidelines, and it blew my mind that so many people ... weren't.

Also re: movies... so when I go to the movies, most of the time it's on a half-priced Tuesday which means tickets are around $6. Sometimes I would go on a regular day and the tickets would be about $13. I'm not going to pay $20 to watch a movie at home, though I value the idea for like a family watching it. But 90% of the time I'm watching movies by myself.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly, people complaining about the $20 on demand charge aren't likely the people who go to the theaters anyway and are looking for more excuses to pirate things. $20 for a new release seems reasonable if you've at least one person watching with you. If you've 3 or more, then it becomes increasingly worth it. With just 2 watching, it's like $10/person which is roughly matinee prices in some areas. Plus you're not going to be gouged on snacks and drinks by the theaters.

Only real downside is you lose out on the theater experience unless you're one of those crazy people that spends inordinate amounts of money on a home theater system and setup. Personally, I'd rather just go to a movie and sit in a giant room with a giant screen with strangers.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have a friend who lives with his grandparents and works retail. Because of this, there's a pretty high risk that he could bring the virus home to his grandparents. I worry about my own family because my older son also works retail, and I have a compromised immune system. I look healthy, but I'm not. My son realizes that this virus could be deadly serious for me, and so he comes in through the back door, doesn't touch anything inside the house where I stay, and goes straight to the shower and then his room. My older daughter goes behind him wiping everything down. He doesn't want to infect me.

This pretty serious. If you don't need to go out, then don't go out.

And for goodness sake! Leave some wipes behind for people that need them! No one shouldn't have to wait in line for over an hour at the hope of a chance of getting wipes and toilet paper. My daughter had to do that yesterday. She came home with a 6-pack of paper towels and no wipes or disinfectant. We've been using bleach and rubbing alcohol.

snippet.textDisplay:
$20 is under, but still rounghly on-par, the price of 2 people seeing a movie at the theatre.

Only, I'm providing the venue, the lighting and energy costs, any surround sound tech, the viewing screen (which is not an iMax 4k, it's a 72 inch in the best case), footing the internet/cable bill...AND I'm missing out on all potential "atmosphere" to theoretically enjoy a cinematic masterpiece alongside 90 other strangers (who are hopefully well maintained) but just as enthusiastic about the movie as I am.

Why am I paying just as much, to be doing all the work, and to miss out on certain aspects that an outing at the movies brings? I left out concessions (cause though are extra) but if I want those I also have to provide and prepare them myself.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think at home rentals are an amazing thing, while some enjoy the theater experience many do not for many different reasons like disabilities or the expense of having a larger family. This would make it more accessible with popular movies that are frequently talked about (like Get Out or Star Wars) and not having to wait months after when it's released and nobody is talking about it anymore. 
Personally I would like to see these rentals at at ~$10, on the bias that I usually only see movies with one other person and I also would never go to the theater alone because of anxiety. $20 is a bit too much for me to justify not just waiting until it hits a streaming service/library.

snippet.textDisplay:
kids are pretty much trained via social media to be narcissistic and the whole "us v. them", social justice mentality to be selfish and callous to the predicaments of others not in their group. YOLO is a popular phrase for a reason. I am not really surprised that they are partying like it's 1999! It's not just Spring Breakers though; I hear men on the radio who sound young and are pissed that March Madness (college basketball tournament) is cancelled and don't care that it might save lives because they are young and "if you are old, just stay home; more tickets for us young guys".


What IS ironic is that these same kids are mad at adults who aren't doing enough about global warming because "you'll be dead soon anyway, but we will have to live with the consequences." Seems like they are not any more concerned with other generations then the claim old people are. They expect other to sacrifice for their future but are unwilling to sacrifice for the futures of others. But they don't even see it. Ironic and sad.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi there, this will be a contraversial comment to make but bare with me. I do understand about the lives of the elderly and sick that will be lost with this pandemic.
But nobody is commenting the destruction of economies and massive amount of people who will loose their jobs (Think about all the servers, cooks, janitors, the people who are already on thin lines of surviving and very likely could loose their incomes)
Nobody will blame the government for the destruction of those lives, but the death of a sick old person is a shock in the media.
Also nobody is talking about herd immunity and how it should be good that the young get the virus because they'll easily get pass it and than protect their communities.
The scenario that most countries want to practice now is eradicating the virus, but what if we do, not all countries will and the virus will be back. And what than? They'll need to repeat all the measures that are now taken.
Sorry this comment is a mess, but im referring to what UK's plan is (which they're still thinking through).

snippet.textDisplay: Can you look into the possibility of GameStop being in HUGE SHIT for refusing to shut down their stores during this pandemic?
